title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures made by individuals. The credit is limited to $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Qualified wind energy property expenditure is defined as an expenditure for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer, including installation fees. Qualified wind energy property refers to a qualifying wind turbine with the original use starting with the taxpayer and a 5-year limited warranty. The qualifying wind turbine must meet performance standards and have a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less. Labor costs for installation and interconnection to the energy grid are included. Expenditures for energy storage mediums like swimming pools are also eligible. For joint occupancy of a dwelling unit, all individuals are treated as one taxpayer for the purpose of determining the allowable tax credit. Each individual can claim a credit for their expenditures on the dwelling unit. Individuals can claim a tax credit for their expenditures on a dwelling unit. For cooperative housing corporation tenant-stockholders, they are treated as having made their proportionate share of any corporation expenditures. Condominium owners are treated similarly for their proportionate share of any condominium management association expenditures. Individuals can claim a tax credit for their expenditures on a dwelling unit, including their proportionate share of any condominium management association expenditures. If less than 80 percent of a qualified wind energy property is used for nonbusiness purposes and energy generation for sale, only the portion of expenditures allocated to these purposes will be considered. Expenditures on qualified wind energy property are considered made when the installation is completed and the property is used for energy generation. Expenditures for building construction are considered made when the structure is used by the taxpayer. Expenditures financed by subsidized energy financing are not included in determining the amount spent on a dwelling unit. Basis adjustments are made for tax purposes. The section discusses basis adjustments for qualified wind energy property expenditures, limiting the credit against regular and alternative minimum tax, and the termination of the section for property installed after December 31, 2008. The text discusses amendments to various sections of the tax code related to energy property expenditures and tax credits. Amendments include changes to sections 25C, 23, 24, 25B, and 26. The text discusses amendments to various sections of the tax code related to energy property expenditures and tax credits, including changes to sections 25C, 23, 24, 25B, and 26. Specific changes include inserting "25C" in place of "and 25B" in multiple sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Amendments to the tax code include changes to section 1400C(d) and the table of sections for subpart A of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1, inserting "25C" after "this section" and adding a new item after section 25B. The amendments made by this section apply to expenditures after December 31, 2002, for taxable years ending after that date. Subsection (b) amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. The section amends the definition of qualified wind energy property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, specifying that it includes wind turbines installed on farms, ranches, or eligible small businesses in the United States before January 1, 2009. The amended definition of qualified wind energy property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes wind turbines located in the United States, owned and used by the taxpayer, with original use commencing with the taxpayer, and carrying a 5-year limited warranty. The credit for such property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to 30% of the property basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The amended definition of qualified wind energy property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes wind turbines with a rated capacity of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance standards. Safety certifications are required for the credit. The energy percentage limitation is amended to 30% of property basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The energy percentage for qualified wind energy property is 30%, while for other energy property, it is 10%. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these amendments is after December 31, 2003.
